page.title: 1.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn that equivalent equations are equations with identical solutions. Specifically, you will explore how applying properties of real numbers can create equivalent equations. Additionally, you will use context to interpret the solution to equivalent equations.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Tell whether two expressions are equivalent and explain why or why not.
  • Identify the moves that can be made to transform an equation into an equivalent one.
  • Explain what it means for two equations to be equivalent and how equivalent equations can be used to describe the same situation in different ways.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.6.1: Exploring Equivalent Expressions 
  • 1.6.2: Expressing Relationships as Equations
  • 1.6.2: Self Check
  • 1.6.3: Exploring Related Equations 
  • 1.6.3: Self Check 
  • 1.6.4: Recognizing Related Equations 

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.6.5: Practice
  • 1.6.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.6.1: Exploring Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Your teacher will assign you one of these expressions:

\( \dfrac {n^2 - 9}{2(4-3)}\qquad \text{or} \qquad (n+3)\cdot \dfrac {n-3}{8-3\cdot2} \)

Evaluate your expression when \( n \) is:

a. \(5\)
b. \(7\)
c. \(13\)
d. \(-1\)

Enter your answers in the box below:

For both expressions, the values are:

a. \(8\)
b. \(20\)
c. \(80\)
d. \(-4\)

page.title: 1.6.2: Expressing Relationships as Equations
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Write as many equations as possible that could represent the relationship between the ages of the two children in each family described. Be prepared to explain what each part of your equation represents.


  1. In Family A, the youngest child is 7 years younger than the oldest, who is 18.

Enter your answer here:

  • \(y=18-7\), for \(y\), the age of the youngest child.
  • \(y+7=18\)
  • \(18−y=7\)
  • \(18−7=11\), where 11 is the age of the youngest child.
  • \(11+7=18\)
  • \(18−11=7\)

  1. In Family B, the middle child is 5 years older than the youngest child.

Sample solutions: 

Enter your answer here:

\( m = y + 5 \), for \( m \), the age of the middle child, and \( y \), the age of the youngest.


  1. Tyler thinks that the relationship between the ages of the children in Family B can be described with \( 2m - 2y = 10 \), where \( m \) is the age of the middle child and \( y \) the age of the youngest.

Enter your answer here:

The equation \( m=y+5 \) represents the relationship of their ages, where \(m\) is the age of the middle child and \( y \) the age of the youngest. Subtracting \( y \) from both sides and multiplying both sides by 2 results in the equation: \( 2m−2y=10 \).




  1. Are any of these equations equivalent to one another? If so, select each equation that is correct. Explain your reasoning.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

All of the equations are equivalent.

 

 


Extending Your Thinking

Here is a puzzle: \( \begin {align} m + m &= N\\ N + N &= p\\ m + p &= Q\\ p + Q &= \text{?} \end{align} \)

Select each expression that could be equal to \(p+Q\).

    • \(2𝑝+𝑚\)
    • \(4𝑚+𝑁\)
    • \(3𝑁\)
    • \(9𝑚\)


Enter your answer here:

2p+m and 9m are equal to p+Q.

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Use inverse operations and add 6 to each side of the equation.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way. Use inverse operations to add 6 to each side of the equation. The answer is \(3x = 24\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way. If you divide terms by 3, you must divide ALL terms in the equation by 3. The answer is \( 3x = 24 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way. If you use inverse operations to bring 18 over to the other side of the equation, you must subtract 18 from both sides of the equation. The answer is \( 3x = 24 \).

page.title: 1.6.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is a correct next step to create an equation equivalent to \( x - 0.2x - 4.2 =13.4 \)?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Combine like terms so that \( x - 0.2x=0.8x \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by 10 can help get rid of the decimal; however, you must multiply both sides by the same quantity. The answer is \( 0.8x - 4.2 =13.4 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Since the 4.2 was subtracted in the original equation, it should have been added to both sides. The answer is \( 0.8x -4.2 =13.4 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: If one side is multiplied by 2, the other side must also be multiplied by 2. The answer is \( 0.8x -4.2 =13.4 \).

page.title: 1.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Select all the equations that have the same solution as the equation \(3x-12=24\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.6.3 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(15x-60=120,\;3x=36,\;x-4=8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Select all the equations that have the same solution as \(2x-5=15\).

Correct! \(2x=20,\;2x-20=0,\;4x-10=30\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.6. to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are \(2x=20,\;2x-20=0,\;4x-10=30\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. Select all of the equations that are equivalent to: \(x + 0.4x - 4.2 =12.8\).

Correct! 

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.6.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(1.4x\;-\;4.2\;=12.8,\;1.4x\;=\;17,\;14x\;-\;42\;=128,\;14x\;=170\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Select all of the following at are equivalent to \(3x -6 =12.\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.6.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are \(3(x-2) = 12\), \(x - 2 =4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. Identify which step the mistake is made in finding an equivalent equation to \(2(x - 4) = 16\).

Step 1: \(2x -4 = 16\)
Step 2: \(2x =20\)
Step 3: \(x =10\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.6.3 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Step 1 has the mistake.The 2 should be distributed to BOTH terms in the parenthesis. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. Identify which step the mistake is made in finding an equivalent equation to \(2x +3x -4 = 20\).

Step 1: \(5x - 4 =20\)
Step 2: \(5x = 16\)
Step 3: \(x =16/5\)

Correct! 

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.6.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Step 2 has the mistake, The 4 should be ADDED to both sides of the equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Identify which step the mistake is made in finding an equivalent equation to \(7x - 4x - 5 =16\).

Step \(1: 3x -5 =16\)
Step 2: \(3x = 21\)
Step 3: \(x =62\)

Correct! 

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.6.3 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Step 3 has the mistake. The 3 should be DIVIDED on both sides of the equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Fill in the blank to complete the equivalent equation to 3(x - 5) = 30.  Enter only integers.

\(3x\)- ____ =30

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.6.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 15.  Distribute the 3 to the 5 with multiplication. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Fill in the blank to complete the equivalent equation to \(\frac x2-5=11\).  Enter only integers.

\(x\) - ______ = 22

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.6.3 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 10. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. Fill in the blank to complete the equivalent equation to \( 3(x - 9) = 24\).  Enter only integers.

\(x\) - ____ = 8

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.6.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 9. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Equivalent Equations

Equivalent equations are equations that have the same solutions. They are often found by using inverse operations or by multiplying each term in the equation by the same value.

Example 1: Write three equivalent equations to \( 4x - 2 = 8 \).

Equivalent Equation A

Add 2 to both sides.

\( 4x = 10 \)

Equivalent Equation B

Divide each term by 2.

\( 2x - 1 =4 \)

Equivalent Equation C

Multiply every term by 3.

\( 12x - 6 = 24 \)


Try It: Finding Equivalent Equations  

Write down one equivalent equation to \( 3x + 5 = 15 \) using inverse operations or multiplication.
Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here are some possible ways to find equivalent equations to \( 3x + 5 = 15 \):

Equivalent Equation A

Subtract 5 from both sides.

\(3x = 10 \)

Equivalent Equation B

After subtracting 5, divide both sides by 3.

  \(x\;=\;\frac{10}3\)

Equivalent Equation C

Multiply every term by a number.

Make sure you multiply EVERY term by the same number.

Example:
\( (2)3x + (2)5 = 15(2) \)
\( 6x + 10 = 30 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.6.3: Exploring Related Equations
page.contents:
Activity

With a partner, discuss the following situations and their equations. When talking about each equation, you will need to discuss what the solution means in the context of the situation and if certain values are in fact solutions.

Remember, if equations are equivalent and operations are applied correctly to both sides, the solution remains the same in all equivalent equations. If the operations are not applied to both sides properly, the solution will change.

1. Noah is buying a pair of jeans and using a coupon for 10% off. The total price is $56.70, which includes $2.70 in sales tax. Noah’s purchase can be modeled by the equation:

\( x - 0.1x + 2.70 = 56.70 \)

Discuss with a partner:

a. What does the solution to the equation mean in this situation?
b. How can you verify that 70 is not a solution but 60 is the solution?

Enter your answers to questions 1a and 1b here:

a. The solution is the price of a pair of jeans.

b. 70 can be substituted into the equation to make a false statement: 
\( 70-0.1(70) + 2.70 = 56.70 \)
\( 65.70 = 56.70 \) False

60 can be substituted into the equation to make a true statement: 
\( 60-0.1(60) + 2.70 = 56.70 \)
\( 56.70 = 56.70 \) True


2. Here are some equations that are related to \( x - 0.1x + 2.70 = 56.70 \). Each equation is a result of performing one or more moves on that original equation. Each can also be interpreted in terms of Noah’s purchase.

Equation A

\( 100𝑥−10𝑥+270=5,670 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation A here:


Every term was multiplied by 100. The equation is equivalent to Noah’s equation. The price is now expressed in cents instead of dollars. 60 is a solution.


Equation B

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=54 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation B here:

Subtract 2.70 from both sides of the equation. The answer is still in dollars. 60 is a solution.


Equation C

\( 0.9𝑥+2.70=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation C here:

\( x \) and \( 0.1x \) were correctly combined to create an equivalent equation to Noah’s original equation. 10% off means paying 90% of the original price. 90% of the original price plus sales tax is $56.70. 60 is still a solution.


Video: Looking at Equivalent Equations

Watch the following video to learn more about why these are equivalent equations.



3. Here are some other equations. For each equation, determine what move was made or how the equation could be interpreted. Then, check if 60 is the solution to the equation.

Equation D

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation D here:

Sales tax was not included on the left but was included on the right. This equation is not equivalent to Noah’s original equation. The price after using the coupon for 10% off before sales tax is not the same as the price after using the coupon for 10% off including the sales tax, $56.70. 60 is not a solution.


Equation E

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=59.40 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation E here:

Subtract 2.70 from the left and add 2.70 to the right. The same operation must be done to both sides of an equation to keep it balanced and to create an equivalent equation. The price after using the coupon for 10% off is not equal to 56.70 plus tax. 60 is not a solution.


Equation F

\( 2(𝑥−0.1𝑥+2.70)=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation F here:

The left side was multiplied by 2. Two pairs of jeans after the 10% discount and sales tax cost 56.70. 60 is not a solution.


4. Which of the six equations are equivalent to the original equation? Be prepared to explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Equations A, B, C are equivalent to the original. Interpreting equations can help you understand the cost of items you buy!

page.title: 1.6.4: Recognizing Related Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A cardboard box, which weighs 0.6 pound when empty, is filled with 15 bags of beans and a 4-pound bag of rice. The total weight of the box and the contents inside it is 25.6 pounds. One way to represent this situation is with the equation \( 0.6 + 15b + 4 = 25.6 \).

1. In this situation, what does the solution to the equation represent?

Enter your answer here:

The solution is the weight of a bag of beans.


2. Identify all the equations that are equivalent to \( 0.6 + 15b + 4=25.6 \).

  • Equation A: \( 15b + 4 = 25.6 \)
  • Equation B: \( 15b + 4 = 25 \)
  • Equation C: \( 3(0.6 + 15b + 4) = 76.8 \)
  • Equation D: \( 15b = 25.6 \)
  • Equation E: \( 15b = 21 \)

Enter your answer here:

The correct answers are B, C, E. Correctly applying the properties of real numbers and using inverse operations helps you recognize equivalent equations.

page.title: 1.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Properties of Equality

Subtraction Property of Equality

For any real numbers \( a \), \( b \), and \( c \),
if \( a = b \),
then \( a−c = b−c \).

Addition Property of Equality

For any real numbers \( a \), \( b \), and \( c \),
if \( a = b \),
then \( a+c = b+c \).

Division Property of Equality

For any real numbers \( a \), \( b \), and \( c \), and \( c \neq 0 \),
if \( a = b \),
then \( \frac{a}{c} = \frac{b}{c} \).

Multiplication Property of Equality

For any real numbers \( a \), \( b \), and \( c \),
if \( a = b \),
then \( ac = bc \).

 
When you add, subtract, multiply, or divide the same quantity from both sides of an equation, you still have equality.

For equations to be equivalent, inverse operations are used and must be applied to both sides of an equation so it remains balanced.

Inverse operations are operations that “undo” other operations.

Example 1: 

Solve \( 3x =15 \).

Since 3 is being multiplied by \( x \), to solve for \( x \), divide both sides by 3.

\( \frac{3x}{3}=\frac{15}{3} \)

\( x=5 \)

Example 2: 

Solve \( \frac{x}{2}+4=12 \).

Original equation.

  \( \frac{x}{2}+4=12 \)

Subtract 4 from both sides.

  \( \frac{x}{2}+4-4=12-4 \)

Simplify.

  \( \frac{x}{2}=8 \)

Multiply both sides by 2.

  \( 2\times\frac{x}{2}=8\times2 \)

Simplify.

\( x=16 \)

Try It: Properties of Equality

Denae bought 6 pounds of grapes for $10.74. What was the cost of one pound of grapes?

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Step 1: Identify the variable.

\( g \): cost for one pound of grapes

Step 2: Write an equation.

\( 6g = 10.74 \)

Step 3: Solve for \( g \). Divide BOTH sides by 6.

 \( \frac{6g}{6}=\frac{10.74}{6} \)

Step 4: Simplify to solve.

\( g=1.79 \)

The grapes cost $1.79 per pound.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.6.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Tell whether two expressions are equivalent and explain why or why not.

  • Identify the moves that can be made to transform an equation into an equivalent one.

  • Explain what it means for two equations to be equivalent, and how equivalent equations can be used to describe the same situation in different ways.

 

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

 

  • 1.6.1 Exploring Equivalent Expressions  

    • In this activity, you substituted values into equivalent expressions to show they are equivalent. 

  • 1.6.2 Expressing Relationships as Equations

    • In this activity, you wrote equivalent equations given different relationships.

  • 1.6.2 Self Check 

  • 1.6.3 Exploring Related Equations

    • In this activity, you identified changes that were made to create equivalent equations then determined if other equations were also equivalent after certain moves were made to the equation.

  • 1.6.3 Self Check 

  • 1.6.4 Recognizing Related Equations

    • In this activity, you determined which equations in a given group were all equivalent to each other.

 

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.6.5: Practice



Checking In 


On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about being able to perform the learning goals of this lesson? 


1 - I’m totally lost!

2 - I could use some more help.

3 - I mostly understand.

4 - I can do it.

5 - I’ve got this!


If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.



To continue to the next lesson, select “Lesson 1.7: Explaining Steps for Rewriting Equations” below.
